122 Arterburn,  Weak perfect compactness and generalized adjoints
compact iff T ( S ) is weakly compact.  A Б - space X will be called weakly perfect iff for every Б - space Y and weakly compact T : Z -> У,  Г is perfectly weakly compact.  A Б - space X is weakly imperfect iff given an infinite-dimensional Б - space Y there exists a weakly compact T : X -> Y which is not perfectly weakly compact. 
A Б - space is weakly mixed iff it is neither weakly perfect nor weakly imperfect. 
If X and Y are normed linear spaces it is easily seen that a map T : X- > F is perfectly weakly compact iff Tq \ Х- >( Б ( У ), TF ' | R ( T )) is compact. 
2.  1 Lemma.  Let X and Y be normed linear spaces.  A compact operator T : X ~> Y is fully [ perfectly ] compact iff fully [ perfectly ] weakly compact. 
Proof,  ( a ) If T is fully compact,  T { S ) is compact,  hence weakly compact. 
If T is not fully compact,  T { S ) is not closed,  hence not weakly closed,  so T { S ) cannot be weakly compact.  •
( b ) If T is perfectly compact,  T ( S )~ ( closure with respect to R ( T )') is compact,  hence weakly compact.  But T { S )~ coincides with the R { T )' closure of F ( iS ), so T is perfectly weakly compact. 
If T is not perfectly compact,  there is a sequence < T ( 6 *) which converges to y ^ R { T ). Then every subsequence of {?/„} converges weakly to г /, whence T { S )~ ( closure with respect to R ( T )' topology ) is not weakly sequentially compact,  so is not weakly compact.  Hence T is not perfectly weakly compact. 
The following analogues of [ 5,  lemma 2 ] and [ 5,  lemma 4 ] are readily established. 
2.  2 Lemma.  Let IF,  Z,  F and Z be normed linear spaces. 
( i ) If P : W X is onto X,  T : X Y is perfectly weakly compact ^ and U : Y Z is
continuous,  then TP and UT are perfectly weakly compact. 
( ii ) Operators with finite dimensional range are perfectly weakly compact. 
( iii ) Scalar multiples of perfectly weakly compact operators are perfectly weakly compact. 
( iv ) The sum of perfectly weakly compact operators need not be perfectly weakly compact. 
( y ) If T : X -> Y is perfectly weakly compact and P : IF -> Z is bounded,  then TP
need not be perfectly weakly compact. 
2.  3 Lemma,  ( i ) Spaces isomorphic to weakly perfect,  weakly mixed,  or weakly imperfect spaces are weakly perfect,  weakly mixed,  or weakly imperfect,  respectively. 
( ii ) Let Z = Zi Ф Zg.  If X ^ is weakly imperfect,  so is X.  If X is weakly perfect, 
so are Zi and Zg.  If Zi is weakly mixed and Zg is weakly perfect,  X is weakly mixed. 
If Zi and Zg are weakly perfect,  X is weakly perfect. 
( iii ) If a B-space X is a continuous linear image of a B-space Y and Y is weakly
perfect,  so is X. 
The following theorem follows from 2.  1 and establishes several weakly imperfect spaces. 
2.  4 Theorem.  An imperfect space is weakly imperfect.  A weakly perfect space is perfect. 
2.  6 Theorem.  A reflexive B-space X is weakly perfect,  hence perfect.
